facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 177 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 177 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 23, 1958 of Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 515 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 23, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 515 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under section 307, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the Punjab High Court dismissing the appellants appeal against his conviction under s. 307, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Bimla Devi married to appellant in October 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Bimla Devi, P. W. 7, was married to the appellant in October, 1951.

facts.text: Relations between Bimla Devi and appellant strained by 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Their relations got strained by 1953 and she went to her brothers place

facts.text: Bimla Devi went to her brother's place and stayed there for about a year.

anchor.surface_text: and she went to her brothers place and stayed there for about a year, when she returned to her husbands place

facts.text: Bimla Devi returned to husband's place on assurance from appellant's maternal uncle that she would not be maltreated.

anchor.surface_text: when she returned to her husbands place at the assurance of the appellants maternal uncle that she would not be maltreated in future.

facts.text: Bimla Devi ill-treated after return, health deteriorated due to maltreatment and deliberate undernourishment.

anchor.surface_text: She was, however, ill-treated and her health deteriorated due to alleged maltreatment and deliberate undernourishment.

facts.text: In 1956, Bimla Devi deliberately starved, not allowed to leave house, sometimes given morsel as to beggars.

anchor.surface_text: In 1956, she was deliberately starved and was not allowed to leave the house and only sometimes a morsel or so used to be thrown to her as alms are given to beggars.

facts.text: Bimla Devi denied food for days, given gram husk mixed in water after five or six days.

anchor.surface_text: She was denied food for days together and used to be given gram husk mixed in water after five or six days.

facts.text: In April 1956, Bimla Devi went out of house, caught by brothers Romesh Chander and Suresh Chander, dragged inside, severely beaten, then locked in room.

anchor.surface_text: She managed to go out of the house in April 1956, but Romesh Chander and Suresh Chander, brothers of the appellant, caught hold of her and forcibly dragged her inside the house where she was severely beaten. Thereafter, she was kept locked inside a room.

facts.text: On June 5, 1956, Bimla Devi found room unlocked, mother-in-law and husband away, escaped to Civil Hospital, Ludhiana, met lady Doctor Mrs. Kumar PW2, told sufferings.

anchor.surface_text: On June 5, 1956, she happened to find her room unlocked, her mother-in-law and husband away and, availing of the opportunity, went out of the house and managed to reach the Civil Hospital, Ludhiana, where she met lady Doctor Mrs. Kumar, P. W. 2, and told her of her sufferings.

facts.text: Appellant and his mother went to hospital, tried to take Bimla Devi back, not allowed by lady Doctor.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his mother went to the hospital and tried their best to take her back to the house, but were not allowed to do so by the lady Doctor.

facts.text: Social workers informed brother Madan Mohan, who came to Ludhiana, learned facts, sent letter to Police Station on June 16, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Social workers got interested in the matter and informed the brother of Bimla Devi, one Madan Mohan, who came down to Ludhiana and, after learning all facts, sent information to the Police Station by letter on June 16, 1956.

facts.text: Madan Mohan's letter stated Bimla Devi on death bed, serious condition, deliberate attempt by husband, mother-in-law, brothers-in-law, sister-in-law; kept locked, beaten, starved.

anchor.surface_text: In his letter he said My sister Bimla Devi Sharma is lying in death bed. Her condition is very serious. I am told by her that deliberate attempt has been made by her husband, mother-in-law and brother-in-law and sister-in-law. I was also told that she was kept locked in a room for a long time and was beaten by all the above and was starved.

facts.text: On June 16, 1956 at 9:15 p.m., Dr. Miss Dalbir Dhillon sent memo to police that patient Bimla Devi very ill, may collapse.

anchor.surface_text: The same day, at 9-15 p.m., Dr. Miss Dalbir Dhillon sent a memo to the police saying My patient Bimla Devi is actually ill. She may collapse any moment.

facts.text: Shri Sehgal, Magistrate PW9, recorded Bimla Devi's statement on night of June 16, 1956, noted blood transfusion, used left thumb impression.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Sehgal, Magistrate, P.W. 9, recorded her statement that night and stated in his memo Blood transfusion is taking place through the right forearm and consequently the right hand of the patient is not free.

facts.text: Photographs of Bimla Devi showed extreme emaciation, hollow cheeks, skeletal appearance, cadaverous countenance.

anchor.surface_text: The impression I formed on looking at the two photographs of Bimla was that at that time she appeared to be suffering from extreme emaciation. Her cheeks appeared to be hollow. The projecting bones of her body with little flesh on them made her appearance skeletal.

facts.text: Punjab High Court found basic allegations of starvation and maltreatment by Bimla Devi true.

anchor.surface_text: After considering the evidence of Bimla Devi and the Doctors, the learned Judge came to the conclusion So far as the basic allegations are concerned, which formed the gravamen of the offence, the veracity of her statement cannot be doubted.

facts.text: Punjab High Court rejected argument that Bimla Devi's emaciation due to prolonged illness, not starvation.

anchor.surface_text: After having given anxious thought and careful consideration to the facts and circumstances as emerge from the lengthy evidence on the record, I cannot accept the argument of the learned counsel for the accused, that the condition of acute emaciation in which Bimla Devi was found on 5th of June, 1956, was not due to any calculated starvation but it was on account of prolonged illness

facts.text: Punjab High Court found story of ill-treatment and attempt to precipitate end convincing, conduct of accused and mother on June 5, 1956 significant.

anchor.surface_text: The story of Bimla Devi as to how she was illtreated, and how, her end was attempted to be brought about or precipitated, is convincing, despite the novelty of the method in which the object was sought to be achieved. The conduct of the accused and of his mother on 5th of June, 1956, when soon after Bimla Devis admission in the hospital they insisted on taking her back home, is significant and almost tell-tale.

facts.text: Appellant acquitted of offence under s.342 IPC by Additional Sessions Judge, benefit of doubt, though movements restricted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was acquitted of the offence under s.342, Indian Penal Code, by the Additional Sessions Judge, who gave him the benefit of doubt, though he had come to the conclusion that Bimla Devis movements were restricted to a certain extent.

facts.text: Punjab High Court held offence under s.307 IPC proved.

anchor.surface_text: Having come to these findings, the learned Judge considered the question whether on these facts an offence under s. 307, Indian Penal Code, had been established or not. He held it proved.

facts.text: Bimla Devi found in acute emaciation on June 5, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: the condition of acute emaciation in which Bimla Devi was found on 5th of June, 1956

Section 307 of the Indian Penal Code reads Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge, and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine

concepts.interpretation: The act need not be the penultimate act; a series of acts in a course of conduct, such as regular starvation, constitutes an 'act' under the section if done with intention or knowledge that if death caused it would be murder.

holdings.text: In view of the finding of the Court below about Bimla Devis being confined and being deprived of regular food in pursuance of a scheme of regularly starving her in order to accelerate her end, the responsibility of the appellant for the condition to which she was brought up to the 5th of June, 1956, is clear.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the finding of the Court below about Bimla Devis being confined and being deprived of regular food in pursuance of a scheme of regularly starving her in order to accelerate her end, the responsibility of the appellant for the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Findings of confinement and deliberate starvation negate claim of merely providing funds/food; appellant directly responsible for scheme to accelerate death.

holdings.text: It should follow that the ingredients of an offence of attempt to commit culpable homicide not amounting to murder should be the same as the ingredients of an offence of attempt to commit that offence under s. 511.

anchor.surface_text: It should follow that the ingredients of an offence of attempt to commit culpable homicide not amounting to murder should be the same as the ingredients of an offence of attempt to commit that offence under s. 511. We have held this day in Abh

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 307 and 308 use identical language; s.308 attempts would otherwise fall under general s.511 provision.

holdings.text: On a parity of reasoning, a person commits an offence under s. 307 when he has an intention to commit murder and, in pursuance of that intention, does an act towards its commission irrespective of the fact whether that act is the penultimate act or not.

anchor.surface_text: On a parity of reasoning, a person commits an offence under s. 307 when he has an intention to commit murder and, in pursuance of that intention, does an act towards its commission irrespective of the fact whether that act is the penultimate act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends reasoning from s.308/s.511 and Abhayanand Mishra v. State of Bihar; attempt requires intention and act towards commission, not penultimate act.

holdings.text: The word act again, does not mean only any particular, specific, instantaneous act of a person, but denotes, according to s. 33 of the Code, as well, a series of acts. The course of conduct adopted by the appellant in regularly starving Bimla Devi comprised a series of acts and therefore acts falling short of completing the series, and would therefore come within the purview of s. 307 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: The word act again, does not mean only any particular, specific, instantaneous act of a person, but denotes, according to s. 33 of the Code, as well, a series of acts. The course of conduct adopted by the appellant in regularly starving

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33 IPC defines 'act' to include series of acts which form same transaction; regular starvation is such a series towards causing death by murder.

holdings.text: In the present case, the intervening fact which thwarted the attempt of the appellant to commit the murder of Bimla Devi was her happening to escape from the house and succeeding in reaching the hospital and thereafter securing good medical treatment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show intentional starvation with knowledge that if continued would cause death amounting to murder; escape was intervening fact per Emperor v. Vasudeo Balwant Gogte.

precedents.citation: Abhayanand Mishra v. The State of Bihar  1

anchor.surface_text: Abhayanand Mishra v. The State of Bihar  1  that a person commits the offence of attempting to commit a particular offence, when he intends to commit that particular offence and, having made preparations and with the intention to commit that offence does an act towards its commission and that such an act need not be the penultimate act towards the commission of that offence, but must be an act during the course of committing such offence.

precedents.case_name: Abhayanand Mishra v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: a person commits the offence of attempting to commit a particular offence, when he intends to commit that particular offence and, having made preparations and with the intention to commit that offence does an act towards its commission and that such an act need not be the penultimate act towards the commission of that offence, but must be an act during the course of committing such offence

anchor.surface_text: Queen Empress v. Nidha  1 . Nidha, who had been absconding, noticing certain chowkidars arrive, brought up a sort of a blunderbuss he was carrying, to the hip and pulled the trigger. The cap exploded, but the charge did not go off. He was convicted by the Sessions Judge under ss. 299 and 300 read with s. 511, and not under s. 307, Indian Penal Code, as the learned Judge relied on a Bombay Case Regina v. Francis Cassidy  1

precedents.cited_proposition: views on what constitutes an attempt to murder under s. 307 IPC, including necessity of last proximate act
precedents.cited_holding: if a person who has an evil intent does an act which is the last possible act that he could do towards the accomplishment of a particular crime that he has in his mind, he is not entitled to pray in his aid an obstacle intervening not known to himself

anchor.surface_text: Regina v. Francis Cassidy  1 -in which it was held that in order to constitute the offence of attempt to murder, under s. 307, the act committed by the person must be an act capable of causing, in the natural and ordinary course of events, death. Straight, J., both distinguished that case and did not agree with certain views expressed therein.

precedents.cited_proposition: act to constitute attempt to murder under s. 307 must be capable of causing death in natural course

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Vasudeo Balwant Gogte  1  a person fired several shots at another. No injury was in fact occasioned due to certain obstruction. The culprit was convicted of an offence under s. 307. Beaumont, C. J.,said at p. 438 I think that what section 307 really means is that the accused must do an act with such a guilty intention and knowledge and in such circumstances that but for some intervening fact the act would have amounted to murder in the normal course of events.

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 307 means the accused must do an act with guilty intention and knowledge such that but for intervening fact it would amount to murder in normal course
precedents.cited_holding: I think that what section 307 really means is that the accused must do an act with such a guilty intention and knowledge and in such circumstances that but for some intervening fact the act would have amounted to murder in the normal course of events.

anchor.surface_text: Mi Pu v. Emperor  1  a person who had put poison in the food was convicted of an offence under s. 328 read with s. 511, Indian Penal Code, because there was no evidence about the quantity of poison found and the probable effects of the quantity mixed in the food. It was therefore held that the accused cannot be said to have intended to cause more than hurt.

precedents.cited_proposition: conviction under s.328/511 where insufficient evidence of intent to cause death due to poison quantity

anchor.surface_text: Jeetmal v. State  2  it was held that an act under s. 307, must be one which, by itself, must be ordinarily capable of causing death in the natural ordinary course of events. This is what was actually held in Cassidys Case  3  and was not approved in Niddhas Case  4  or in Gogtes Case  4 .

precedents.cited_proposition: act under s.307 must be ordinarily capable of causing death by itself

anchor.surface_text: Rex v. White  6 . In that case, the accused, who was indicted for the murder of his mother, was convicted of attempt to murder her. It was held that the accused had put two grains of cyanide of potassium in the wine glass with the intent to murder her. ... This supports our view.

precedents.cited_proposition: completion or attempted completion of one of a series of acts intended to result in killing is an attempt to murder even if that act alone would not result in killing
precedents.cited_holding: the completion or attempted completion of one of a series of acts intended by a man to result in killing is an attempt to murder even although this completed act would not, unless followed by the other acts, result in killing

anchor.surface_text: The course of conduct adopted by the appellant in regularly starving Bimla Devi comprised a series of acts and therefore acts falling short of completing the series, and would therefore come within the purview of s. 307 of the Code.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction under s. 307 IPC for attempt to murder by starvation upheld as the course of conduct constituted a series of acts towards commission of murder
